newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: IMF says endorses Philippine monetary policy.
newsitem.headline: IMF says endorses Philippine monetary policy.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund on Tuesday rejected as false Manila newspaper reports which said the IMF was worried over discrepancies in Philippine economic data.
"A number of reports in this morning's press attributed views to the IMF. These reports are false," a statement from the IMF's Manila office said.
Several Manila newspapers reported on Tuesday that the IMF was concerned about discrepancies in economic data provided by the government.

The reports, quoting unnamed sources, said an IMF team due to arrive in Manila this week for a routine review of the economy would look into abrupt changes in the monetary programme and balance of payment figures.
"References to IMF concerns about abrupt changes in monetary policy and conflicting data have absolutely no basis in fact," the IMF statement said.
The IMF team's visit is a regularly scheduled mission covering economic developments and prospects in the Philippines, it said.
The Philippines is under a three-year IMF programme which ends next year.
"The IMF endorses the monetary policy of the authorities that has and continues to remain well within the agreed programme framework," the statement said.
A separate report released by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on Tuesday pointed out "unusually large" errors in the Philippines' 1995 balance of payments data.

The Manila-based bank said it was not possible to gauge the full extent of the miscalculation and ADB economist Srinivasa Madhur told a news conference data problems were common in the initial stages of a country's economic liberalisation programme.
